title: Blaming firefighters for the Grenfell fire lets the real culprits off the hook
text:
Action has to be taken now – it is what the bereaved families and survivors want (Picture: Dinendra Haria/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)

Earlier this week, the Grenfell Tower inquiry phase one report was leaked to the media.

Firstly, it must not be understated how this has impacted the ability of the Grenfell bereaved families, survivors and residents to have had the time to calmly digest the findings.

What followed was a media onslaught of the firefighters who attended on the night, when in reality, the fire at Grenfell Tower occurred amid years of cuts to public services, deregulation and privatisation of housing and housing services, as well as a culture of ignoring the concerns of social housing residents and social inequality.

All of this played a part in the Grenfell disaster – and the public inquiry should have opened with this context.

Instead, it opened with act two, scene one, focusing on details about the fire on that fateful night.

Advertisement

Advertisement

This has been the tone of the whole inquiry from the start – mostly blaming the firefighters – with no historical context, ultimately letting the government and private companies off the hook with ‘extra time’.

In the report, the chairman, Sir Martin Moore-Bick, has made a range of recommendations primarily for the fire service, as well as owners and managers of high-rise buildings.

He condemned the London Fire Brigade’s ‘stay put’ policy, the risk assessment of the tower and highlighted that the firefighters were not educated in the dangers associated with the cladding on the outside of the building. Moore-Brick also concluded that the tower’s cladding failed to comply with building regulations.

The tone of the whole inquiry has been mostly blaming the firefighters – with no historical context, ultimately letting the government and private companies off the hook with ‘extra time’ (Picture: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images)

Let’s hope there is money in the coffers to implement these changes.

However, there are no recommendations for the fitting of sprinkler systems or for a complete ban on the use of combustible materials on high-rise buildings.

According to Moore-Brick, this will be looked at in phase two – which reveals the lack of urgency by the government to remove current combustible cladding.

If we are to prevent this from happening again, more urgency is needed. This should have been the focus of the inquiry from the beginning.

In 2009, six people were tragically killed in a fire at Lakanal House in Camberwell, after which the coroner made a series of safety recommendations for the government to consider.

Advertisement

Advertisement

These recommendations were sat on by then housing minister Gavin Barwell, who delayed a fire safety review in changes to building regulations for high-rises after these deaths.

This had devastating effects for what would eventually happen at Grenfell eight years later.

Many political parties’ decisions were implicated, including the government at all levels: the council; the planning department; the building management company (KCTMO); building inspectors and the building industry as a whole – from architects to contractors, manufacturers and retailers.

How could they all have failed in their professional responsibilities and in their duties of care so abysmally?

Left unchecked, the social, economic and political forces that led to Grenfell will no doubt lead to further horrific – but predictable and preventable – disasters.

Peeling back every layer of the Grenfell disaster, it seems to me that the same issues are at play.

Regulations were relaxed and eliminated, warnings were ignored and costs were cut, while profits and council reserves increased – all to the detriment of hard-working citizens, the poor and the powerless with many lives lost, solely for the benefit of the wealthy and powerful.

Action has to be taken now – it is what the bereaved families and survivors want.

If the inquiry had begun with act one scene one, the recommendations would look starkly different.

Then, the real ‘villains of the piece’ would be in the media headlines, rather than the firefighters who risked their own lives to save people in a building that no-one should have been living in, with a fire that was unprecedented.

Advertisement

Any type of disaster is possible given the huge scope of past and present governments’ extreme erosion of safety standards through programmes of deregulation, privatisation, outsourcing/subcontracting, localism and austerity.

The inquiry must fully investigate all such issues. The fire was simply the final act in a long line of actions that appear to me to have led, inevitably but predictably, to the Grenfell Tower fire and its attendant loss of life.

Left unchecked, the social, economic and political forces that led to Grenfell will no doubt lead to further horrific – but predictable and preventable – disasters.

I am also minded that there is nothing on the statute books that makes it mandatory for a government to act on any public inquiry’s recommendations.

This will be about political will, so let’s hope they will.

RIP to all those lives taken in this tragedy.
